Author: Marchesino, Francesco
Title: Copia de una lettera di Napoli che contiene li stupendi, et gran prodigii apparsi sopra a Pozzolo
Summary: Francesco Marchesino, a Milanese publisher, was among the curious observers of the sudden eruption of Mount Nuovo. He documented this natural event in a letter, subsequently printed, describing the awe-inspiring phenomena of the eruption and the fear it generated. Marchesino recounted a devotional procession culminating in the ritual beheading of Saint Gennaro in the chapel where the martyrdom occurred in the vicinity of Pozzuoli. In the following passages, the letter focused on the Viceroy's visit to the disaster-stricken areas, accompanied by philosophers who framed the event within Aristotelian theses.

Author: Falconi, Marcantonio
Recipient/dedicatee information: All'illustrissima signora marchesa della Padula
Title: Dell'incendio di Pozzuolo
Printer information: Napoli, Giovanni Sultzbach, 1539 (Si venne per Marco Antonio Passaro alli Ferri vecchi)
Summary: Marco Antonio delli Falconi, a renowned scholar in classical languages, was a contemporary witness to the 1538 eruption of Monte Nuovo. His work is noteworthy for describing the panic and and flight of the people of Pozzuoli during the disaster. The text offers a detailed account of the eruption's initial hours and cites Aristotle's theories to explain seismic and volcanic activity. Falconi's work defends the peripatetic perspective on natural disasters' natural origins, contrasting with contemporary prophecies. His optimism is based on the observation that the consumption of dead birds and fish had not harmed anyone following the eruption.
Reference copy-ies: Florence, Biblioteca Nazionale Centrale TARG. MISC.228.4; Naples, Biblioteca della Società Napoletana di Storia Patria SISMICA 07.E. 038

Title: Ragionamento del terremoto del nuovo monte, del aprimento di terra in Pozuolo, nel anno 1538, e dela significatione d'essi, per Piero Giacomo da Toledo
Printer information: Stampata in Nap. per Giouanni Sulztbah alemano à 22 de Genaro 1539 con gratia, e, priuilegio.
Summary: Pietro Giacomo de Toledo, a witness to the 1538 eruption, authored a work explaining the disaster and dedicated to the Viceroy. This text, presented as a dialogue between Peregrino and Suessano, used Aristotelian concepts to describe the eruption's causes and effects. The dialogue explained the eruption through a metaphor based on the workings of the human body. Toledo emphasized two origins in seismic activity, a final cause (God) and a formal cause (resulting from terrestrial movements). He also discussed subterranean winds generating earthquakes in regions without openings. Toledo's outlook for the near future was pessimistic, especially for Pozzuoli.

Author: Del Nero, Francesco
Title: Lettera di noui avisi de Pezolo et delle bocche del foco nuouamente aparse apresso a Napoli, & de la Pronosticatione di quello et di tutto el Successo insino a questo Giorno Adi XVI d'Ottobre M.D.XXXVIII
Summary: Printed version of the contents of the letter that Francesco Del Nero, a witness to the 1538 eruption, wrote to Niccolò del Benino, giving a vivid account of the impact of the disaster. Del Nero, a Florentine businessman and relative of Machiavelli, described the transformation of the once enchanting Pozzuoli into a fiery nightmare. He also expressed his inability to comprehend the immense volume of incandescent materials ejected from the crater in just two days.Del Nero mentioned the scholarly discussions surrounding the event, acknowledging the writings of Simone Porzio and the viceroy Pedro de Toledo's response, which involved digging numerous deep pits to extinguish the fire. Del Nero's letter reflects the popular perception of the eruption during his time.Del Nero compared the eruption to a pyrotechnic display at Castel Sant'Angelo, like the one held to celebrate the marriage between Margaret, daughter of Emperor Charles V, and Ottavio Farnese in November 1538, the month after the date of the letter.
Reference copy-ies: Munich, Bayerische Staatsbibliothek Res/4 Phys.sp. 304,9

Summary: The description of the eruption of Huaynaputina occupies pages 73-80 of the Augustinian work. Torres attributes the eruption to the sins of Arequipa and recalls that already in the past the inhabitants had suffered the wrath of God with the earthquake of 1587. He reflects on the causes of the event, which, having occurred during the rainy season, should have led him to believe that the cause was not natural but divine. He also mentions how some preachers, such as the Jesuit Alonso Ruiz, had prophesied God's imminent punishment. On the disaster, he says he consulted the texts of the Jesuit Martín del Río, Juan Solórzano Pereira and Antonio de la Calancha. The author describes the phases of the calamity and how the noise generated by the eruption was mistaken by the viceroy for a naval battle with English pirates. Of particular note is the definition of Huaynaputina as an 'Indian Vesuvio'. The work of the Society of Jesus and the Augustinians in assisting the population is particularly noteworthy.

Author: Calancha, Antonio de la
Recipient/dedicatee information: Dedicada a nuestra / señora de Gracia, singular Patrona i Abogada de la dicha Orden
Title: Coronica moralizada del orden de San Augustin en el Peru con sucesos egenplares en esta Monarqvia ...
Printer information: Por Pedro Lacavalleria, en la calle de la Libreria
Summary: The friar, who witnessed the earthquake, refers to the comet of December 1618 that would have announced the tremor (pp. 488-489). He recounts the effects of the earthquake on the topography, the sea and the buildings of the city. According to De La Calancha, it caused 350 deaths (p. 489). He praises the action of the Augustinians in contrast to other religious orders who decided to leave the city (pp. 489-490). The poor decided to appoint De La Calancha as their representative to prevent the city from being moved. De La Calancha claims that he succeeded in his mission despite having the viceroy and the Audiencias against him (pp. 498-499). De La Calancha also refers to a prodigy that occurred after the earthquake, but denies the disastrous consequences attributed to it by the population (p. 490). The Augustinian friar also narrates the salvation of the painter Leonardo de Jaramillo (pp. 493-494) and the transfer of the temple of the Virgin of Guadalupe and her image because of the earthquake (pp. 566-567).

Moreover, one day when the religious were praying to the Virgin, they saw the image turn and smile at them. The friar tells about the damages that the earthquake caused to the cathedral. The only intercession of the Virgin managed to avoid the complete destruction of Lima.
